questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious at home. He has a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus and reports recurrent episodes of hypoglycemia. His wife mentions that he has been trying a new "natural" supplement along with his prescribed insulin. On arrival, his blood glucose is 45 mg/dL. Laboratory tests reveal undetectable serum C-peptide levels. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his hypoglycemia?
Where in the tubule would a patient with severe central diabetes insipidus have the lowest tubular fluid osmolality?

A 44-year-old man has had worsening exercise intolerance for the past year. On physical examination, he has 4/5 motor strength in the extremities, but has no muscle pain or loss of joint mobility. He has pitting edema to the knees. A deltoid muscle biopsy specimen is obtained. The figure shows the immunohistochemical staining pattern with antibody to dystrophin (A, normal; B, patient). What is the most likely diagnosis?
Match the following:

A 15-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of an 8-month history of fatigue, intermittent postprandial abdominal bloating and discomfort, foul-smelling, watery diarrhea, and a 7kg (15-lb) weight loss. She developed a pruritic rash on her knees 3 days ago. Physical examination shows several tense, excoriated vesicles on the knees bilaterally. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Her hemoglobin concentration is 8.2 g/dL and mean corpuscular volume is 76 um3. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

options.label: D
options.text: Granulomatous inflammation of the terminal ileum

Over the past year, she has had multiple episodes of bacterial skin and respiratory infections requiring antibiotic treatment. Physical examination reveals silvery hair, pale skin with multiple areas of scarring from previous infections. A peripheral blood smear is obtained and shown below. Which of the following disorders is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of weight loss, fever, and a persistent cough. Imaging of the chest reveals bilateral apical opacities with cavitation. A lung biopsy is performed, which is shown below. Which of the following cell surface markers is most specific for the cells predominantly found surrounding the necrotic tissue?

A 42-year-old woman presents to the clinic for evaluation of blood in her stool, fatigue, and weight loss over the past 2 months. However, her father died of colorectal cancer at age 45, and her younger sister has been treated for endometrial cancer. Colonoscopy reveals a right-sided mass without polyps, and biopsy shows adenocarcinoma. Which of the following gene mutations is most likely responsible for her condition?

A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of weight loss, heat intolerance, palpitations, and insomnia over the past 4 months. Her vital signs are blood pressure 140/85 mm Hg, pulse 110/min, and regular. On examination, the thyroid gland is diffusely enlarged and non-tender. Laboratory studies reveal decreased serum TSH and elevated free thyroxine (T4) levels. Methimazole is initiated as treatment. Which of the following processes is most likely inhibited by this treatment?

options.label: C

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for follow-up after experiencing a near-drowning incident that led to ARDS. He was mechanically ventilated for 2 weeks and subsequently discharged. The patient now reports persistent exertional dyspnea and mild fatigue. Which of the following parameters is most likely increased compared to a child with normal cardiopulmonary function?

A 17-year-old girl presents to the clinic with headache, fatigue, fever, and a persistent dry cough. She reports that the symptoms began 2 weeks ago during a school trip. A chest X-ray reveals diffuse interstitial infiltrates. Laboratory testing shows hemolytic anemia with elevated reticulocyte count. Blood samples drawn into anticoagulated tubes are stored on ice, and visible clumping is observed when cold. Which of the following pathogens is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?

A 45-year-old man with a history of chronic alcohol use disorder is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious at home. He was last seen well 8 hours ago. Respiratory rate: 10/min, Oxygen saturation: 88% on room air. Arterial blood gas analysis reveals: pH: 7.22 PaCO₂: 60 mm Hg HCO₃⁻: 24 mEq/L Which of the following is the most likely current acid-base status in this patient?

A 68-year-old postmenopausal woman presents for evaluation of her low bone density noted during a routine screening. She is started on oral risedronate to address her bone loss. What is the primary mechanism through which this medication improves bone density?

A 58-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to persistent pain and swelling in her hands for the past 10 years. She reports morning stiffness lasting 2 hours, which improves with activity. On examination, there is gross deformity of multiple joints in both hands. Wrist Xray is given below. The condition causing these findings would most likely affect which of the following regions of the spine?

A 68-year-old man presents to the clinic due to progressively worsening pain in his lower limbs for the past 6 months. He reports the pain is deep and aching and worsens with activity. There is no history of trauma or fever. On examination, the legs are bowed with palpable warmth over the shins, and imaging shows trabecular thickening and cortical bone expansion in both tibiae and fibulae. Which of the following laboratory findings is most likely seen in this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Normal calcium, Normal phosphorus, Normal ALP

options.label: C

options.label: D

questions.explanation: Ans. D) Normal calcium, Normal phosphorus, High ALP

questions.text: A researcher is investigating the structure of the sarcomere using skeletal muscle obtained from an experimental animal. He develops monoclonal antibodies directed against a specific skeletal muscle protein and finds that these antibodies disrupt the binding of actin to structural support elements within the sarcomere. Which of the following labeled regions do these antibodies most likely bind?
What is the normal insensible water loss?

A 45-year-old man participates in a research study. He undergoes percutaneous skeletal muscle biopsy. Microscopic analysis shows his type I and type II muscle fibers are clustered in groups in contrast to a normal intermixed pattern, as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the changes observed in this patient’s skeletal muscle? Which of the following is the most likely cause of the observed findings on histology?
questions.correct_answer: C. Motor axon degeneration and reinnervation
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Motor axon degeneration and reinnervation

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the clinic with recurrent nausea, bloating, and early satiety for the past 3 months. She reports occasional vomiting of undigested food several hours after eating. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus with long-standing poor glycemic control and associated neuropathy. Physical examination reveals a soft, non-tender abdomen with normal bowel sounds. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy shows no structural abnormalities. A macrolide is prescribed after which patient reports significant improvement in her symptoms. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely responsible for this patient's improvement?
questions.correct_answer: A. Agonistic activity on motilin receptors
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Agonistic activity on motilin receptors

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset, severe left flank pain that radiates to his groin. He has a history of hypertension and atherosclerosis. His blood pressure is 152/90 mm Hg, pulse is 100/min, and respiratory rate is 20/min. A contrast-enhanced CT scan reveals a wedge-shaped perfusion defect in the left kidney, consistent with a renal infarct. Which of the following histologic changes is most likely to occur in the affected renal tissue over the next several days?

A 63-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to worsening cough over the past several months. She initially experienced a dry cough, but now it has become productive with large amounts of yellowish sputum. The patient also complains of breathlessness on moderate exertion. She has had two hospitalizations this year for respiratory infections. The patient has a significant history of smoking one pack per day for the past 35 years and has made multiple unsuccessful attempts to quit. Her oxygen saturation is 89% at rest and decreases to 84% with moderate exertion. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?

A previously healthy 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a one-week history of diffuse abdominal pain. Her temperature is 39.1°C (102.3°F). Physical examination shows numerous scars and excoriations along both arms, scleral icterus, and tender hepatomegaly. Serum studies shown below: Which of the following is least likely to be seen in the liver biopsy of this patient?
The second phase of saliva secretion involves:

options.label: B
options.text: Passive Na+ reabsorption, active CI- reabsorption, passive K+ secretion, active secretion of HCO3-

options.label: C

options.text: Active Na+ reabsorption, passive Cl- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, passive secretion of HCO3-

questions.correct_answer: D. Active Na+ reabsorption, passive Cl- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, passive secretion of HCO3-
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Active Na+ reabsorption, passive Cl- reabsorption, active K+ secretion, passive secretion of HCO3-

questions.text: Identify the correct order of End plate potential at the neuromuscular junction:

options.label: A
options.text: Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate

options.label: B
options.text: Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate→ Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release

options.label: C
options.text: Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate → Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal

options.label: D
options.text: Action potential at motor end plate → Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens

questions.correct_answer: A. Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate

Explanation:

  • • Ans. A. Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate
  • • Explanation:
  • • At the neuromuscular junction (NMJ), the sequence of events leading to muscle contraction begins with the binding of acetylcholine (Ach) to its receptors on the motor end plate. This binding opens ligand-gated Na⁺ channels, allowing an influx of sodium ions, which depolarizes the muscle membrane and generates an action potential. The action potential travels along the motor neuron to the axon terminal, where it triggers the opening of voltage-gated Ca²⁺ channels. The entry of calcium ions into the axon terminal facilitates the exocytosis of Ach into the synaptic cleft, which then binds to receptors on the muscle fiber to propagate the signal for muscle contraction.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Ligand-gated Na⁺ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate → Ca²⁺ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release: This sequence incorrectly initiates with the opening of ligand-gated Na⁺ channels before Ach is released. In reality, Ach must first be released to bind to these channels and cause their opening.
  • • Option B. Ligand-gated Na⁺ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate → Ca²⁺ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release:
  • • Option C. Ach Release → Ligand-gated Na⁺ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate → Ca²⁺ entry in Axon Terminal: Ach release is a result of Ca²⁺ entry, not the initial step. This option reverses the correct order of events.
  • • Option C. Ach Release → Ligand-gated Na⁺ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate → Ca²⁺ entry in Axon Terminal:
  • • Option D. Action potential at motor end plate → Ca²⁺ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand-gated Na⁺ channel opens: This sequence incorrectly places the action potential at the motor end plate before Ach release. The action potential at the motor end plate is a result of Ach binding, not the precursor to Ca²⁺ entry.
  • • Option D. Action potential at motor end plate → Ca²⁺ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand-gated Na⁺ channel opens:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence at the neuromuscular junction is:
  • ➤ The correct sequence at the neuromuscular junction
  • ➤ Ca2+ entry in Axon Terminal → Ach Release → Ligand gated Na+ channel opens → Action potential at motor end plate

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with a history of non-Hodgkin lymphoma comes to the clinic for follow-up. She recently completed a round of chemotherapy. Immunohistochemistry confirms these cells are undergoing apoptosis. Which of the following substances, released from mitochondria, most likely initiated the observed cellular changes?
Which of the following sodium transporters are present maximally in early part of PCT? Na-K-ATPase Na-glucose cotransport Na-H antiporter Na-HCO3 symporter

A 25 yr old women G2P1L1 is brought to the emergency at 30 weeks gestation in active labor. The patient had severe anemia during pregnancy and received multiple blood transfusions during past months. An uncomplicated Vaginal delivery is performed and 2.5 kg infant is delivered. Post operatively she continues to bleed and receives a transfusion of 1 unit of packed RBC. One hour later, the patient appears to have flank pain and in acute distress. Temperature is 101°F, pulse 115/min and BP is 92/66 mm Hg. Foley catheter shows dark brown urine. Further evaluation is most likely to show:

A 15-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department due to confusion, abdominal pain, and vomiting for the past two days. Her parents report that she has been excessively thirsty and urinating frequently over the last few weeks. On examination, her vital signs are as follows: temperature 37.2°C (99°F), pulse 110/min, blood pressure 90/60 mm Hg, and respiratory rate 28/min. Laboratory investigations reveal the following: Glucose 320 mg/dL Sodium 132 meq/l Potassium 5.2 meq/l Bicarbonate 12 meq/l Arterial pH 7.25 Urinalysis: Positive for urine and ketones Which of the following factors most likely contributed to the development of this patient's condition?

A 45-year-old woman comes to the office for follow-up one month after a stroke that resulted in speech difficulties. The patient’s speech is fluent with appropriate cadence, but she is unable to correctly repeat phrases that the physician verbalizes. She can follow 2- and 3-step commands without difficulty. Which of the following brain regions is most likely impaired in this patient?

An 18-month-old girls has developed seborrheic skin eruptions over the past 3 months. She has had recurrent upper respiratory and middle ear infections with streptococcus pneumoniae for the past year. Physical examination indicates that she also has hepatosplenomegaly and generalized lymphadenopathy. Her hearing is reduced in the right ear. A skull radiograph shows an expansile, 2 cm lytic lesion involving the right temporal bone. Laboratory studies show no anemia, thrombocytopenia, or leukopenia. The mass is curetted. Which of the following is most likely to be seen on microscopic examination of this mass?
A man who is fond of exotic cuisine develops perioral numbness after eating the pufferfish. The given poisoning is due to which of the following toxins?
Erythropoietin is produced by all of the following organs except:

A 38-year-old weightlifter is competing in a powerlifting championship. After successfully lifting a barbell weighing 200 kg, he holds the weight for a few seconds before his arms suddenly give way, and he drops the weight involuntarily. The lifter does not experience pain, and his arms feel weak but recover quickly. This sudden muscle relaxation was most likely initiated by which of the following structures?

An 8-year-old boy was referred to a pediatric endocrinologist because of growth retardation. Lab tests showed increased serum growth hormone levels but very low serum levels of insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1). Further exams led to the diagnosis of Laron dwarfism. Which of the following drugs would be most appropriate for this boy?

A 48-year-old woman presents with progressive facial puffiness and lower extremity edema over the past 2 months. Laboratory studies reveal serum creatinine of 1.9 mg/dL, albumin level of 2.7 g/dL, and 3+ proteinuria on urinalysis. A kidney biopsy is performed, and light microscopy with hematoxylin and eosin staining is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s kidney findings?

A 40-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of fatigue, weight loss, salt craving, and dizziness upon standing. She has no significant medical history and takes no medications. Her mother was recently diagnosed with hypothyroidism. On examination, her blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg supine and 80/50 mm Hg standing. Laboratory results reveal the following: Sodium 129 meq/l Potassium 5.9 meq/l Chloride 100 meq/l Bicarbonate 21 meq/l Creatinine 1.4 mg/dl BUN 38 mg/dl Which of the following in circulating hormone levels are expected in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Cortisol low, Aldosterone low, ADH high, Norepinephrine high

options.label: B
options.text: Cortisol normal, Aldosterone low, ADH normal, Norepinephrine normal

options.label: C
options.text: Cortisol low, Aldosterone low, ADH normal, Norepinephrine normal

options.label: D
options.text: Cortisol high, Aldosterone low, ADH high, Norepinephrine high

questions.correct_answer: A. Cortisol low, Aldosterone low, ADH high, Norepinephrine high
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Cortisol low, Aldosterone low, ADH high, Norepinephrine high

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath, productive cough, and fatigue for the past 5 days. His medical history includes heart failure with reduced ejection fraction and chronic hypertension. On physical examination, dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds are noted over the left lower lung. Chest X-ray is shown. Thoracentesis is performed, and the results are as follows: Which of the following is most likely contributing to the pathogenesis of this patient's pleural effusion?

Physiologists studying hemoglobin function in patients with respiratory disorders are evaluating changes associated with oxygen loading and unloading. During the transition from point 1 to point 2 on the graph shown below, hemoglobin molecules are most likely to release which of the following?

A 3-year-old boy is brought to the clinic due to failure to thrive, frequent urination, and excessive thirst. Examination shows frontal bossing, delayed growth, and mild muscle weakness. Laboratory studies reveal hypokalemia, hypophosphatemia, glucosuria, and a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. Which of the following structure/function combinations is most likely defective in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Distal convoluted tubule - Generation of ammonia

options.label: B
options.text: Distal convoluted tubule - Reabsorption of bicarbonate

options.label: C
options.text: Distal convoluted tubule - Secretion of hydrogen ions

options.label: D
options.text: Proximal convoluted tubule - Reabsorption of bicarbonate

questions.correct_answer: D. Proximal convoluted tubule - Reabsorption of bicarbonate
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Proximal convoluted tubule - Reabsorption of bicarbonate

questions.text: Which of the following is correctly matched:

options.label: B
options.text: Saline washed RBC: Increased risk of allergic reaction

questions.text: A 28-year-old medical student undergoes a tuberculin skin test (TST) as part of a routine health check. He is asymptomatic with no history of recent fever, weight loss, or cough. He receives an intradermal injection of purified protein derivative (PPD) on the inner surface of his forearm. After 48 hours, a raised, erythematous induration measuring 18 mm is observed at the injection site. Which of the following interactions is critical to the development of this patient’s skin reaction?

options.label: A
options.text: CD14 on macrophages with bacterial lipopolysaccharide

options.label: B
options.text: CD16 on NK cells with IgG-coated infected cells

options.label: C
options.text: CD18 on neutrophils with ICAM-1 on endothelial cells

options.label: D
options.text: CD28 on T lymphocytes with CD80/86 on epidermal dendritic cells

questions.correct_answer: D. CD28 on T lymphocytes with CD80/86 on epidermal dendritic cells
questions.explanation: Ans. D) CD28 on T lymphocytes with CD80/86 on epidermal dendritic cells

questions.text: Thalidomide should not be used in which of the following conditions?

A 58-year-old man presents to the emergency department with facial swelling and difficulty swallowing. He reports waking up with swelling of his lips and tongue, along with a sensation of throat tightness. He recently started taking enalapril for hypertension 1 month ago. He has no history of allergies or similar symptoms in the past. On examination, there is no wheezing or urticaria. Vital signs are stable. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism responsible for this patient's symptoms?

A 25-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after fainting at home. She has been experiencing severe thirst and frequent urination for several days. Her medical history is significant for a traumatic brain injury two weeks ago from a motor vehicle accident. Her fluid volume and osmolality changes are shown below. The solid line represents a normal individual, and the dotted line represents this patient. Which of the following conditions is most likely causing this patient’s findings?
Sodium iodide symport is present in all of the following except:

A 62-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of progressive shortness of breath and nonproductive cough. He has a history of long-standing rheumatoid arthritis, for which he previously took methotrexate but stopped treatment a year ago. He denies tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drug use. On physical examination, the patient has end-inspiratory crackles at the lung bases and no wheezing. A chest X-ray is shown. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient’s pulmonary symptoms?

A 66-year-old woman has experienced pain in the area around the left knee for the past 6 weeks. MRI shows a well-circumscribed 4-cm mass superior and inferior to the patella. The mass is within soft tissue, without bony erosion. A biopsy of the mass is obtained and on microscopic examination shows a biphasic pattern of spindle cells and epithelial cells forming glands. Karyotypic analysis of tumor cells shows a t(X;18) translocation. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Members of a family with a history of renal cancers undergo ultrasound screening. Two adults are found to have multifocal and bilateral renal mass lesions. Biopsies are obtained, and microscopic examination shows a papillary pattern. A mutation involving which of the following genes is most likely to be found in this family?
Which of the following statement is false regarding mesial temporal lobe epilepsy?

options.label: A
options.text: It results in focal seizures with dyscognitive features

options.label: B
options.text: The person experiences an aura before the seizure

options.label: C
options.text: It is associated with a family history of epilepsy

options.label: D
options.text: Seizures can be controlled with anticonvulsants such as carbamazepine

questions.correct_answer: D. Seizures can be controlled with anticonvulsants such as carbamazepine
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Seizures can be controlled with anticonvulsants such as carbamazepine

questions.text: In the absence of ADH, which of the following sites would have the highest tubular fluid osmolality?
Match the CD markers-

A 30-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of irregular menstrual periods, progressive weight gain, and easy bruising over the past 8 months. She reports feeling increasingly weak, especially while climbing stairs or standing from a seated position. On examination, her blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg, BMI is 32 kg/m², and she has central obesity with a prominent fat pad in the supraclavicular region. Sun-exposed areas and skin creases show hyperpigmentation with signs of hirsutism. Which of the following sets of laboratory findings is most likely to be observed in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: 24-hour cortisol Increase, Serum ACTH increase, Serum DHEAS increase

options.label: B
options.text: 24-hour cortisol Increase, Serum ACTH decrease, Serum DHEAS decrease

options.label: C
options.text: 24-hour cortisol Increase, Serum ACTH normal, Serum DHEAS increase

options.label: D

questions.text: Cortical homunculus representation of the body in the cerebrum is:

A 26-year-old man developed sudden severe abdominal pain. On physical examination, he had marked abdominal tenderness and guarding. Laboratory studies showed calcium-12.2 mg/dL; phosphorus-2.6 mg/ dL; creatinine, 1.1 mg/dL; and parathyroid hormone-62 pg/mL (normal: 9-60 pg/mL). During surgery, four enlarged parathyroid glands were found and excised, with re-implantation of one half of one gland. After the surgery, his calcium concentration returned to normal. Three years later, he had an episode of upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage. An endoscopy and biopsy specimen showed multiple benign gastric ulcerations. Abdominal MRI indicated multiple 1- to 2-cm mass lesions in the pancreas. Which of the following additional neoplasm lesions is he most likely to have?

A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with fever, abdominal pain, and persistent fatigue for 2 days. On examination, her blood pressure is 130/90 mm Hg, and she is pale with scattered petechiae on the extremities. Laboratory evaluation reveals low hemoglobin, elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase, thrombocytopenia, and normal prothrombin time/partial thromboplastin time. Peripheral blood smear shows schistocytes. Urinalysis shows proteinuria and hematuria. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Match the following drugs with the reactivation of infections they are associated with:

A 43-year-old man comes to the clinic due to shortness of breath and fatigue over the past 2 weeks. He reports significant weight gain, swelling around the ankles, and profound fatigue. Laboratory findings include red blood cell casts in urine and elevated creatinine. Immunofluorescence microscopy shown. Which of the following light microscopy findings is most likely to be seen in this patient’s renal biopsy?
Which of the following conditions is not caused by Trinucleotide repeat mutations involving non- coding regions?

A 58-year-old woman comes to the office for follow-up monitoring of type 2 diabetes mellitus. She was diagnosed with diabetes 6 years ago and follows a strict diet to control her blood sugar levels. Serum creatinine is 1.1 mg/dL, and serum potassium is 3.9 mEq/L. Further laboratory evaluation reveals increased urinary albumin excretion, but a conventional urinalysis is within normal limits. In addition to starting antihyperglycemic treatment, which of the following is the best pharmacotherapy for this patient?
True about anaphylactoid reaction are all except:

A 60-year-old woman comes to the office for management of her type 2 diabetes mellitus. She has been on metformin for the past 2 years and has made lifestyle modifications, including diet and exercise, but her glycemic control remains suboptimal. The physician decides to start pioglitazone to improve her glycemic control. Before initiating this therapy, the patient should be educated about which of the following potential adverse drug effects?
What is the mechanism of action of aprepitant?

71-year-old man has had decreased urine output <500 mL per day for the past 3 days. Physical examination shows vital signs with temperature 37° C, pulse 88/min, respiratory rate 18/min, and blood pressure 85/60 mm Hg. He has peripheral edema and diffuse rales on auscultation of the chest. Urinalysis shows specific gravity 1.019 and no protein, blood, glucose, ketones, WBCs, RBCs, or casts. His serum creatinine is 3.3 mg/dL, and urea nitrogen is 62 mg/dL. The fractional excretion of sodium (FENa) is <1%. Which of the following underlying conditions is he most likely to have?
Match the following:
Which among the following are Incorrect about baroreceptors?

options.label: A
options.text: Located in the muscular layer of the vessels

options.label: C
options.text: More sensitive to Pulsatile pressure than Constant Pressure

options.label: D
options.text: Maximal activity of baroreceptors occurs at 200 mm Hg

questions.correct_answer: A. Located in the muscular layer of the vessels
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Located in the muscular layer of the vessels

questions.text: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a nonpruritic rash, fatigue, and decreased urination. Physical examination shows multiple erythematous, purpuric papules on his trunk and extremities that do not blanch when pressed. Serum creatinine is elevated and urinalysis shows red blood cell casts and protein. Serum complement levels are decreased. Renal biopsy shows subendothelial immune complex deposits with granular immunofluorescence and tram-track basement membrane splitting. Further laboratory evaluation of this patient is most likely to show the presence of which of the following antibodies?

A 14-year-old boy is hospitalized due to worsening confusion and vomiting of blood for the past 2 days. Medical history is notable for irritability and declining school performance over the past year. He is oriented to person but disoriented to time and place. During hospitalization, the patient rapidly deteriorates and passes away. Autopsy examination reveals Nodular liver, Splenomegaly, Basal ganglia atrophy with increased copper content. The most likely cause of this patient’s condition is an abnormality in which of the following physiologic processes?
Which of the following cardio selective beta-blockers has been shown to decrease mortality in patients with congestive heart failure?

A 67-year-old man has had increasing weakness, fatigue, and weight loss over the past 5 months. He now has decreasing vision in both eyes and has headaches and dizziness. His hands are sensitive to cold. On physical examination, he has generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory studies indicate a serum protein level of 15.5 g/dL and albumin concentration of 3.2 g/dL. A bone marrow biopsy is performed, and microscopic examination of the specimen shows infiltration by numerous small plasmacytoid lymphoid cells with Russell bodies in the cytoplasm. Which of the following additional laboratory findings is most likely to be reported for this patient?
questions.correct_answer: D. Monoclonal IgM spike in serum
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Monoclonal IgM spike in serum

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with a history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation is undergoing a stress ECG for evaluation of his cardiac function for which a drug has been administered. Pre-test resting ECG reveals a QRS duration of 90 msec (normal: 80-120 msec) and a corrected QTc interval of 400 msec (normal: ≤440 msec). Post-test ECG findings during exercise show a QRS duration of 130 msec with no change in QTc interval. Which of the following medications is the most likely cause of these ECG findings?

A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to progressive lethargy, fatigue, and nausea over the past month. She has also experienced constipation, muscle weakness, increased thirst, and frequent urination. She reports taking high doses of calcium and vitamin D supplements after reading they could improve bone health. On examination, she is stuporous and has dry mucous membranes. questions.text: An infant of 3 months presents with recurrent severe infections, including pneumonia, chronic diarrhea, and oral candidiasis. He has an absence of thymic shadow on chest X-ray. Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ SCID is characterized by recurrent severe infections, absence of thymic shadow, and very low levels of adenosine deaminase, highlighting defects in both T and B cell function.

questions.text: An athlete collapsed suddenly and dies. He had an abnormal septal thickening. His sibling also expired due to a cardiac condition earlier. His cardiac biopsy image is shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is characterized by asymmetrical septal hypertrophy, disorganized cardiac muscle fibers, and is commonly associated with sudden death in young athletes, particularly during exertion.

questions.text: In the below question mechanical receptors are given with their functions. Choose the correctly matched pair.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pacinian corpuscle - Fast Vibration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pacinian corpuscles are responsible for detecting fast vibrations, and Ruffini endings detect skin stretch.

questions.text: Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in a patient with the image of chromosome 15 represented here? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prader-Willi syndrome is caused by a deletion on the paternal chromosome 15q11-q13 or by maternal uniparental disomy, and is characterized by obesity due to hyperphagia, intellectual disability, and specific behavioral traits.

questions.text: Which one of the following is incorrect about iron transport? (NEET PG 2024)

options.label: A

options.label: C

questions.correct_answer: A. Iron is converted from ferrous to ferric form before absorption through apical membrane.

Ans. A) Iron is converted from ferrous to ferric form before absorption through apical membrane.

questions.text: Oxygen sensitive channels in peripheral chemoreceptors are for which of the following ion? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) K+

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The primary ion involved in oxygen sensing in peripheral chemoreceptors is potassium (K+). The closure of oxygen-sensitive potassium channels during hypoxia is a crucial step in the signaling pathway that regulates respiratory response to low oxygen levels.

questions.text: How muscle spindle able to detect the length while muscle is contracting? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Nuclear bag fibers

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nuclear bag fibers in the muscle spindle are responsible for detecting the rate of change in muscle length during muscle contraction, making them essential for proprioception and motor control.

questions.text: Which of the following is earliest to rise in myocardial infarction? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ischemia modified albumin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In the event of a myocardial infarction, certain biomarkers are released into the bloodstream as a result of cardiac muscle injury.
  • • Among the three early markers of myocardial injury , three are particularly significant: myoglobin, heart-type fatty acid binding protein (HFABP), and ischemia modified albumin (IMA). Of these three, ischemia modified albumin is the earliest to rise and also the earliest to fall in response to myocardial ischemia. This rapid change makes it a valuable early diagnostic marker for detecting myocardial infarction.
  • • three early markers of myocardial injury
  • • myoglobin, heart-type fatty acid binding protein (HFABP), and ischemia modified albumin (IMA).
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Troponin: Troponins are highly specific markers for myocardial injury and are considered the gold standard for diagnosing myocardial infarction. However, they do not rise as early as ischemia modified albumin. Typically, troponin levels start to rise 4-6 hours after the onset of myocardial infarction.
  • • Option A. Troponin:
  • • Option C. LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase): LDH is an enzyme found in almost all body tissues and is not specific to cardiac tissue. It is a later marker of myocardial infarction, usually rising within 24-48 hours after the onset of symptoms.
  • • Option C. LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase):
  • • Option D. CK MB (Creatine Kinase-MB): CK-MB is a specific isoenzyme found in heart muscle and is used as a marker for myocardial infarction. However, it does not rise as early as ischemia modified albumin. CK-MB levels typically start to increase 3-6 hours after myocardial infarction.
  • • Option D. CK MB (Creatine Kinase-MB):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ischemia modified albumin is the earliest biomarker to rise in the event of a myocardial infarction, making it a crucial early indicator for diagnosis.

questions.text: An elderly patient underwent investigations which revealed Hb 9 g/dL, TLC 50,000/mm³, ↑PT, ↑aPTT, low platelet count, and increased D-dimers. Which of the following is the likely gene affected in the patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) PML- RARA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ APL (acute promyelocytic leukemia) is characterized by the PML-RARA fusion gene and is highly associated with DIC, which can be identified by a combination of bleeding tendencies and abnormal coagulation profiles.

questions.text: A patient with a history of TB presents with hemoptysis. X-ray is shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Aspergilloma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aspergilloma is a fungal infection that commonly occurs in pre-existing lung cavities from conditions such as tuberculosis. It presents as a cavity with a fungal ball inside and can cause hemoptysis, which may be severe.

questions.text: Sour taste is mediated by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) TRPV1 Channel

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sour taste is mediated by the activation of ion channels, particularly the TRPV1 channel and acid-sensitive ion channels, in response to H+ ions from acidic substances

questions.text: Which of the following drugs, when given with erythromycin, can cause QT prolongation and Torsades de pointes? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Astemizole, when combined with erythromycin, can cause QT prolongation and Torsades de pointes due to its significant effect on cardiac potassium channels, posing a high risk of life-threatening arrhythmias.

questions.text: What mechanism occurs within the zona pellucida of an oocyte to prevent the entry of multiple sperm cells after the initial fertilization?

options.label: B
options.text: Increased membrane potential of the oocyte

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased membrane potential of the oocyte

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cortical reaction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The cortical reaction is essential, as it is the primary defense against polyspermy, ensuring that only one sperm fertilizes the oocyte, thereby maintaining the correct genetic composition of the embryo.

questions.text: A patient from a military background presented with rash, fever, and altered sensorium. There is also a deficiency of the membrane attacking complex. The likely cause can be: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Neisseria meningitidis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients with deficiencies in the membrane attack complex (C5-C9) of the complement system are particularly susceptible to infections caused by Neisseria species, such as Neisseria meningitidis, which can lead to severe conditions like meningococcemia.

questions.text: A person was taking an antihypertensive drug and continued taking it despite developing constipation, dry mouth, and dizziness. He was taking it regularly but forgot to take it during a trip abroad and has now developed a hypertensive emergency. Which antihypertensive was he likely taking? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Clonidine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Clonidine is an antihypertensive medication that can cause dry mouth, constipation, and dizziness, and sudden discontinuation can lead to rebound hypertension, making it crucial for patients to maintain consistent dosing.

questions.text: A 40-year-old farmer presented with retro-orbital pain, conjunctival suffusion, night fever and chills, calf tenderness, cervical lymphadenopathy, hypokalemia, and joint pain. What can be the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)

questions.text: A boy born to a normal father and mother had Hemophilia. Detailed history taking revealed that the mother's side had a family history of similar affected individuals. The children born to this boy are likely to have which of the following? (NEET PG 2024)

options.label: B

questions.text: Identify the transporter of iodine from follicular cells to follicular cavity within the thyroid gland: (NEET PG 2024)

Ans. B) Pendrin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. His blood pressure is 165/92 mm Hg on the left arm and 162/90 mm Hg on the right arm. questions.explanation:
Ans.

questions.text: An athlete who was planning for some kind of physical activity sport comes for a routine health checkup. All routine investigations turned out to be normal with non-significant ECG findings except he had a PR interval of 0.21 seconds. Which of the following is most likely? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) First degree heart block

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A PR interval greater than 0.20 seconds indicates a first-degree AV block, which can be physiological, especially in athletes with high vagal tone.

questions.text: A hospital has reported an outbreak of MRSA infection. On investigation, it was found out that a staff nurse had nasal carriage of MRSA. Which of the following drugs helps in the removal of colonization of bacteria? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Topical mupirocin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Topical mupirocin is the recommended treatment for the nasal decolonization of MRSA, effectively reducing the nasal carriage of the bacteria and thereby decreasing the risk of transmission and subsequent infections.
  • ➤ Topical mupirocin

questions.text: A previously healthy 21-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 4 hours after the sudden onset of shortness of breath and pleuritic chest pain. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 3 years. He is 188 cm (6.2 ft) tall and weighs 70 kg; BMI is 19.8 kg/m. questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in the treatment of Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) has a direct spasmolytic action on gastrointestinal (GI) smooth muscle?

Ans. C) Mebeverine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mebeverine is a direct spasmolytic drug used in the treatment of IBS, acting directly on the GI smooth muscle to relieve spasms and pain.

questions.text: Which of the following is used to monitor PCM toxicity?
When papain acts on a molecule of immunoglobulin, which of the following are the end products? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1 Fc and 2 Fab fragments

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When an immunoglobulin molecule is digested with papain, the end products are 1 Fc fragment and 2 Fab fragments.

questions.text: A patient is presenting with a staggering gait and nystagmus (Rhomberg sign +ve) after a road traffic accident. Which lobe of cerebellum is affected?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Flocculonodular

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The flocculonodular lobe of the cerebellum is crucial for maintaining balance, posture, and controlling the vestibulo-ocular reflex. Damage to this area can lead to symptoms such as a staggering gait, nystagmus, and balance issues, as seen in the case of cerebellar ataxia following trauma.

questions.text: A patient presents with hepatosplenomegaly with bone marrow having 22% plasma cells. The bone marrow biopsy had a pink acellular deposition of material as shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Amyloidosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Amyloidosis can occur as a result of multiple myeloma due to the deposition of abnormal immunoglobulin light chains, which can be identified as acellular pink deposits on histology.

questions.text: Splenectomy is contraindicated in which of the following conditions? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Bone marrow failure

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Splenectomy is contraindicated in bone marrow failure, as the underlying issue resides in the bone marrow's inability to produce blood cells.
